docs.lead_paragraph: House Republican leaders balked today at the idea of helping thousands of laid-off workers by extending unemployment compensation and health care benefits despite a commitment last Friday by Speaker J. Dennis Hastert to consider such legislation. ''The model of thought there, and quite frankly, the model of thought that says we need to go out and extend unemployment benefits and health insurance benefits and so forth is not I think one that is commensurate with the American spirit here,'' said Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader. He said a higher priority was to pass an economic stimulus bill.

headline.main: House Republican Leaders Balk at Any Help for Laid-Off Workers

docs.abstract: House Republican leaders, including Rep Dick Armey and Tom Delay, balk at idea of helping thousands of laid-off airline workers by extending unemployment compensation and health benefits despite commitment by Speaker J Dennis Hastert to consider such legislation; Pres Bush plans to travel to Chicago to thank airline workers, and some are hoping he will offer them some sort of assistance; Rep Richard A Gephardt introduces one of several bills to help laid-off workers; Hastert spokesman reiterates that speaker plans to keep his commitment to Democrats (M)
docs.snippet: House Republican leaders balked today at the idea of helping thousands of laid-off workers by extending unemployment compensation and health care benefits despite a commitment last Friday by Speaker J. Dennis Hastert to consider such legislation.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: The attacks of Sept. 11 took the lives of thousands of loving parents. Perhaps 15,000 children, to judge by early estimates, have lost a father or mother. In many cases, that person was a single parent. In New York City the immediate relief effort has been comprehensive and well organized. But the city and state must undertake a complete follow-through to help children and surviving parents after emergency conditions have subsided. The Family Assistance Center at Pier 94 has offered admirable support to victimized families. Though a forbiddingly impregnable-looking compound on the outside, it offers a relaxed and caring atmosphere inside. A special area for children offers them the chance to play while their parents or guardians seek aid. Facilitators from nonprofit organizations act as guides in obtaining medical assistance, day care and supplemental income. State agencies and insurance companies -- both of which have staff at Pier 94 -- have processed claims for survivors' benefits, even when missing parents have not been declared legally dead.
docs.abstract: Editorial on perhaps 15,000 children who lost parent in Sept 11 terrorist attack; calls on New York City and New York State to undertake complete follow-through to help families after stories fade from front pages
docs.snippet: The attacks of Sept. 11 took the lives of thousands of loving parents. Perhaps 15,000 children, to judge by early estimates, have lost a father or mother. In many cases, that person was a single parent. In New York City the immediate relief effort...

docs.lead_paragraph: When a venerable Colombian company that makes light fixtures badly needed capital, salvation came from an unusual source. A group of former guerrillas, pooling government money they received on laying down their arms, bought 17 percent of the factory three years ago. Today the company, Industrias Rof, on this city's outskirts, is on firm financial footing. The new entrepreneurs, former members of a Marxist urban guerrilla movement, are upgrading machinery and increasing exports.

headline.main: Former Rebels in Colombia Take the Capitalist Road

docs.abstract: Colombia's 'reinsertion program' encourages former Marxist guerrillas to assimilate into society and join legitimate economy; successes include Industrias Rof, venerable lighting company that got influx of capital from former guerrillas who pooled money they got for laying down arms; Maria Elba Salazar, who deserted rebel army two years ago, now runs seafood restaurant in Bogota; photo (S)
docs.snippet: When a venerable Colombian company that makes light fixtures badly needed capital, salvation came from an unusual source. A group of former guerrillas, pooling government money they received on laying down their arms, bought 17 percent of the factory...

docs.lead_paragraph: Maybe it was the finality of it. On Sept. 15, the bond trading firm of Cantor Fitzgerald dropped its missing employees from the payroll. Whether that was prudent or crass depends in large part on one's view of Howard W. Lutnick, the chairman of the firm, which lost almost 70 percent of its New York staff in the attacks on the World Trade Center.

headline.main: Some Families Doubt Sincerity of Cantor
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE TRADING FIRM

docs.abstract: Cantor Fitzgerald dropped its missing employees from payroll on Sept 15, and whether that was prudent or crass depends in large part on one's view of Howard W Lutnick, chairman of firm, which lost almost 70 percent of its New York staff in attacks on World Trade Center; Lutnick's gritty reputation at first was largely obscured by halo effect of his tearful public pledge to keep devastated firm alive so that it could care for more than 600 families bereft by disaster; Cantor families are starting to match those televised promises against details of firm's benefits and are smudging Lutnick's new image with rancor and suspicion; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The House ended nine years of blocking a District of Columbia domestic partners law today, adopting the measure 226 to 194 despite opposition by most of the Republican leadership. Since Washington's City Council passed it in 1992, Congress has thwarted the measure, which would allow city employees to buy health insurance at group rates for their unmarried partners. It would apply to same-sex and opposite-sex couples who live together, including such pairings as a child and a grandparent, or two sisters.

headline.main: House Approves D.C.'s Law On Rights of Domestic Partners

docs.abstract: House ends nine years of blocking District of Columbia domestic partners law, adopting measure 226 to 194 despite opposition by most of Republican leadership (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Influential advisers and key members of Congress expressed opposition today to two of the main Republican proposals for stimulating an already weakened economy as new figures suggested that the terrorist attacks would inflict heavy damage on jobs, spending and the business outlook. Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and Robert E. Rubin, the former treasury secretary, advised Congress against cutting the capital gains tax, the favored approach of many Republicans on Capitol Hill, or reducing corporate income taxes, the idea mentioned by the Bush administration.

headline.main: CONGRESS GETS PLEA TO DROP TAX BENEFITS FOR INVESTORS AND WIDEN ECONOMIC RELIEF

docs.abstract: Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan and former treasury secretary Robert Rubin advise Congress against Republican proposals to cut capital gains tax or corporate income taxes to stimulate lagging economy that has been further weakened by effects of Sept 11 terrorist attack; Rubin, in third appearance on Capitol Hill since attack, joins Greenspan in warning that approach would not provide immediate punch for rebound; photo of two with Sen Max Baucus at Senate Finance Committee hearing; Conference Board reports consumer confidence in sharp decline since attack; other data show steep falloff in retail sales and at least temporary job losses in New York; Greenspan and Rubin recommend only temporary tax cuts that would not create long-term budget problems or push up long-term interest rates at time when federal surplus projections are being scaled back even more (M)
docs.snippet: Influential advisers and key members of Congress expressed opposition today to two of the main Republican proposals for stimulating an already weakened economy as new figures suggested that the terrorist attacks would inflict heavy damage on jobs,...

docs.lead_paragraph: The official number of bodies found in the destruction of the World Trade Center stood at 279 yesterday, and the city medical examiner had identified 209. In all, 6,398 could be missing. Here are glimpses of some of those lives. IVHAN LUIS CARPIO BAUTISTA Things Were Going So Well Last Tuesday was Ivhan Luis Carpio Bautista's day off at Windows on the World. It was also his birthday. But with an extended family back in Peru depending on his paycheck, Mr. Carpio, 24, did not hesitate when a co-worker called that Monday night asking if he would cover a shift. ''He worked all the overtime he could,'' said a cousin, Rita Tatiana Palacio. ''Too many people needed the money, including a niece whose school he paid for.''

headline.main: As Providers, Friends, and Shoulders to Lean On, They Put Others First
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: PORTRAITS OF GRIEF: THE VICTIMS

docs.abstract: Brief sketches of lives of some of World Trade Center attack victims; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Labor-management relations in the airline industry, rocky before Sept. 11, have grown rancorous, with unions enraged at what they say are moves by several carriers to use the national emergency to deny pay or benefits to workers idled as air travel stalls. American Airlines, a unit of the AMR Corporation, said yesterday that the airline's finances had been hurt so badly by the terrorist attacks that it could not afford to pay severance benefits to the thousands of workers that it planned to lay off.

headline.main: Unions at Airlines Assail Management For Denying Benefits

docs.abstract: Airline unions are enraged at what they say are moves by several carriers to use national emergency to deny pay or benefits to workers idled as air travel stalls; American Airlines says carrier's finances have been hurt so badly that it cannot afford to pay severance benefits to thousands of workers that it plans to lay off; union officials criticize American, asserting that least airline can do after Congress approved multibillion-dollar bailout is to make good on its commitments to its workers; American insists company is honoring its contract and is invoking emergency clause that it says allows company to suspend certain commitments under extreme circumstances; its chief executive, Donald J Carty, says he will take no pay for rest of year and urges American employees to agree to voluntary cuts in pay; several union officials and airline workers say United Airlines is leaving some workers in limbo by not calling them to work and not laying them off; say US Airways is citing emergency conditions to override no-furlough clause in certain union contracts; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Labor-management relations in the airline industry, rocky before Sept. 11, have grown rancorous, with unions enraged at what they say are moves by several carriers to use the national emergency to deny pay or benefits to workers idled as air travel...

docs.lead_paragraph: After years of hostility, frosty exchanges and seemingly intractable distrust, Speaker J. Dennis Hastert and the House Democratic leader, Richard A. Gephardt, have bonded. The two sit side by side on television talk shows, something they had never done before last week. They huddle at least once a day on Capitol Hill to talk business. They even go out in public together, sharing the limelight and speaking in dulcet tones about unity and cooperation.

headline.main: Washington Talk; With Bipartisan Zeal, Rival House Leaders Bond

docs.abstract: In wake of terrorist attacks in New York and Washington, Speaker J Dennis Hastert and House Democratic leader Richard A Gephardt have bonded, ending years of hostility, frosty exchanges and seemingly intractable distrust; two sit side by side on television talk shows, huddle daily to talk business and even go out in public together; new bipartisanship has translated into string of legislative victories in response to terrorist attacks; how long two men can keep their caucuses in line is anyone's guess; photo (M)
docs.snippet: After years of hostility, frosty exchanges and seemingly intractable distrust, Speaker J. Dennis Hastert and the House Democratic leader, Richard A. Gephardt, have bonded.    The two sit side by side on television talk shows, something they had never...

docs.abstract: In this lesson, students examine racial profiling of Arab-Americans and Middle Eastern Americans in the wake of the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks in the United States. By considering attitudes and scenarios in groups, student address related issues and possible solutions.
